instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Only one USB C Port working,
threads.message:
have a  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> , one of the USB C port does not work and it says that it is drawing too much power board turns on and works perfectly other wise, would it be one of the USB C Controllers <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>, or <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>?

Using <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Schematic

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Only one USB C Port working,
threads.message:
Do you receive over loading message from macOS when connect a device on that port?
Does that port work as charger at least?

Why don't you use correct schematic???
A link should be already posted on the forum...
